caption: Quite an unusual statue in that it is very tactile. You can feel the individual clay pieces as they were applied in forming the piece but rather than being smoothed off, they remain in their original state.
As an American I found this statue to be a bit random but I loved every bit of it! We see you Thomas Jefferson.

I was in France last week and took an early morning jog along the River Seine. I went to where Thomas Jefferson stood and where they say he found architectural inspiration for his Monticello when looking at Paris‚Äô Hotel Salm. The Hotel de Salm was constructed between 1782 and 1787. Thomas Jefferson was the US ambassador to France from 1785-1789. I believe the statue was dedicated in July 2006, according to the French written on Jefferson‚Äôs statue.  I also went to where the Treaty of Paris was signed at 56 Rue de Jacob, signed in 1783. John Adams (our future 2nd president) was one of the signers of that document. That was the treaty that officially ended the American Revolution. I‚Äôll post pictures of that later.  It was amazing to see so many 18th century buildings still standing in France! Obviously, their history goes beyond US History. We‚Äôre babies, if you put our historical timelines up against each other. üë∂ üòÉ  I‚Äôd like to think that Jefferson‚Äôs Declaration of Independence and our American Revolution inspired the French Revolution of 1789, which led to the beheading of their monarch, King Louis XVI and changing the world.  IG: MattInHistory
Surreal seeing a statue of one of America's founding fathers in the middle of France but if you know history you know exactly why and full respect to the French for honouring him.

There is a bronze statue of Thomas Jefferson that can be seen near Musee d‚ÄôOrsay at the beginning of the footbridge crossing the Seine. This is the works of French sculptor Jean Cardot and was unveiled here in 4 July 2006.  Jefferson was the U.S. Ambassador to France (1785-1789) and 3rd President U.S. President (1801-1809). He is also considered a principle author of U.S. Declaration of Independence from England in 1776.  The monument depicts this important Founding Father of America in stately attire, peering forward while grasping a manuscript or drawings of Monticello in his left hand. It is a nice image of Jefferson and symbol of the long standing American and French ties, relations and friendship.

Knowing he‚Äôd served as Ambassador for roughly 4 years it was still a bit of a surprise to stumble across this statue.  Located right next to the Seine in the 7th Arrondissement. Standing 10ft tall and in bronze to celebrate the 230th Anniversary of Americas Independence.

He is looking at the building. Thomas Jefferson was the father of America, his ideas about, government, liberty and separation of church and state were the cornerstone of my country. He was a friend of Lafayette when he was in France.

Thomas Jefferson (April 13, 1743[a] ‚Äì July 4, 1826) was an American statesman, diplomat, lawyer, architect, philosopher, and Founding Father who served as the third president of the United States from 1801 to 1809.

I never thought I would see a statue of American President Thomas Jefferson here. I was even more delighted because I saw it in Washington last month.

The Thomas Jefferson Statue is a sculpture of American statesman Thomas Jefferson by sculptor Jean Cardot. Jefferson was the principal drafter of the United States Declaration of Independence in 1776, then secretary of state between 1790 and 1793, vice president from 1797 to 1801, third president of the United States from 1801 to 1809. He was also the 2nd Ambassador of the United States United in France. Inaugurated in 2006, the work is located on the Quai Anatole-France at the L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor footbridge, near the Legion of Honor museum.

Thomas Jefferson is considered one of the founding fathers of the United States, as he was one of the founding members of the Republican movement.  Jefferson, the third president of the United States, served as US ambassador in Paris and lived in the Champs-√âlys√©es region. This statue right next to the Passerelle L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor bridge is a small but cute souvenir. If you happen to pass by, don't miss seeing it.
Beautiful statue dedicated to a very important American.

A statue of Tomas Jefferson, by Jean Cardot. He holds in his hands a sketch of the house he will build, inspired by the building of the Legion of Honor.

At the end of the L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor footbridge, a majestic statue of Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826), the most French of Americans, sits on the Quai Anatole France along the Seine. He was in fact ambassador of the United States to France from 1785 to 1789. The 3rd President of the United States (1801-1809) and one of the most eminent Founding Fathers, who notably distinguished himself by the purchase of Louisiana from France from Napoleon Bonaparte 1st Consul for a pittance (doubling the surface area of USA). Napoleon needed money and wanted to prevent the English from taking it. It represents one of Jefferson's greatest political successes. Did he not hesitate to declare that ‚ÄúEvery man of culture has two homelands: his own and France‚Äù. This is well worth a magnificent statue. Inaugurated on July 4, 2004. It was financed in particular by the Florence Gould Foundation, which participated in the restoration of the Statue of Liberty on √éle aux Cygnes.
